Malignant hyperpyrexia (malignant hyperthermia)

Malignant hyperpyrexia (malignant hyperthermia) Genetic susceptibility 1 in 5000 to 1 in 10000, usually autosomal dominant. Complicates 1 in xxx anaesthetics. Susceptible individuals have on average had 3 uneventful GAs before diagnosis. Precipitants: volatile agents, suxamethonium, caffeine, emotional stress. Pathophysiology: loss of skeletal muscle Ca ++ homeostasis; ryanodine receptor defect xxx

Management:

Diagnose:

- Masseter spasm (may be only manifestation)

- Hypermetabolic state:

↑CO2 ↑HR ↑RR ↑VO2 ↓ S P O2

- Hyperthermia, sweating

- Unstable BP, arrhythmias.

Treat:

  1. Get clean circuit, intubate, ventilate 3x normal

  2. Give Dantrolene 1-2mg/kg up to 10mg/kg total

- Decreases Ca++ release from SR.

  1. Cooling: cool iv fluid, sponge skin with water

  2. Ongoing management:

  3. ICU management:

Continue dantrolene for 48hr (prevent retriggering)

Correct hypothermia

Treat pulmonary oedema

Monitor muscle oedema: compartment syndrome

  1. Refer pt. To MH centre, Leeds.

[Halsall, P.J. et al. BJA CEPD Reviews 3 , 5-9(2003).]
